segment.source: How Oobe.xml Works
segment.target: How Oobe.xml Works

segment.source: How Oobe.xml Works
segment.target: How Oobe.xml Works

segment.source: How Oobe.xml Works
segment.target: How Oobe.xml Works

segment.source: Oobe.xml is a content file that you can use to organize text and images and to specify and preset settings for customizing the Windows first experience.
segment.target: Oobe.xml is a content file that you can use to organize text and images and to specify and preset settings for customizing the Windows first experience.

segment.source: You can use multiple Oobe.xml files for language- and region-specific license terms and settings so that users see appropriate information as soon as they start their PCs.
segment.target: You can use multiple Oobe.xml files for language- and region-specific license terms and settings so that users see appropriate information as soon as they start their PCs.

segment.source: By specifying information in the Oobe.xml file, OEMs direct users to perform only the core tasks that are required to set up their PCs.
segment.target: By specifying information in the Oobe.xml file, OEMs direct users to perform only the core tasks that are required to set up their PCs.

segment.source: Windows checks for and loads Oobe.xml in the following locations, in the following order:
segment.target: Windows checks for and loads Oobe.xml in the following locations, in the following order:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefaultOobe.xml
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefaultOobe.xml

segment.source: If you have customizations that span all countries/regions and languages, the Oobe.xml files can be placed in Location 1.
segment.target: If you have customizations that span all countries/regions and languages, the Oobe.xml files can be placed in Location 1.

segment.source: If you're shipping a single-region, single-language system, your custom Oobe.xml file should be placed in the Info (Location 1) or Default (Location 2) directory.
segment.target: If you're shipping a single-region, single-language system, your custom Oobe.xml file should be placed in the Info (Location 1) or Default (Location 2) directory.

segment.source: Those locations are functionally equivalent.
segment.target: Those locations are functionally equivalent.

segment.source: If you're shipping to multiple countries/regions and your OOBE settings require customizations for individual countries/regions, each with a single language, all of your Oobe.xml files should be placed in Locations 4 and 5.
segment.target: If you're shipping to multiple countries/regions and your OOBE settings require customizations for individual countries/regions, each with a single language, all of your Oobe.xml files should be placed in Locations 4 and 5.

segment.source: If you're shipping to multiple countries/regions with multiple languages, the following guidelines apply:
segment.target: If you're shipping to multiple countries/regions with multiple languages, the following guidelines apply:

segment.source: Place country/region-specific information in Location 4.
segment.target: Place country/region-specific information in Location 4.

segment.source: Place language-specific information for each respective country/region in Location 5.
segment.target: Place language-specific information for each respective country/region in Location 5.

segment.source: Single-language deployments
segment.target: Single-language deployments

segment.source: If you're delivering PCs to one country/region in a single language, you should place a single Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.
segment.target: If you're delivering PCs to one country/region in a single language, you should place a single Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.

segment.source: This file can contain all of your customizations to the Windows first experience.
segment.target: This file can contain all of your customizations to the Windows first experience.

segment.source: For example, an English version of Windows that's delivered to the United States can have the following directory structure:
segment.target: For example, an English version of Windows that's delivered to the United States can have the following directory structure:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml

segment.source: If you're delivering PCs to more than one country/region in a single language, and you plan to vary your customizations in different locations, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.
segment.target: If you're delivering PCs to more than one country/region in a single language, and you plan to vary your customizations in different locations, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.

segment.source: This file can contain the default regional settings that you plan to show to the user.
segment.target: This file can contain the default regional settings that you plan to show to the user.

segment.source: You should also include a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.
segment.target: You should also include a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.

segment.source: The Oobe.xml file should also contain the eulafilename node with the name of the customized license terms that you plan to use.
segment.target: The Oobe.xml file should also contain the eulafilename node with the name of the customized license terms that you plan to use.

segment.source: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains unique customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.
segment.target: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains unique customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.

segment.source: After the user has chosen a country/region, these files are used to display additional customizations.
segment.target: After the user has chosen a country/region, these files are used to display additional customizations.

segment.source: For example, an English version of Windows delivered to the United States and Canada can have the following directory structure:
segment.target: For example, an English version of Windows delivered to the United States and Canada can have the following directory structure:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (EULA file name and regional settings)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (EULA file name and regional settings)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content)

segment.source: Multiple-language or region deployments
segment.target: Multiple-language or region deployments

segment.source: If you're delivering PCs to one or more countries/regions and are delivering PCs running Windows with additional language packs, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.
segment.target: If you're delivering PCs to one or more countries/regions and are delivering PCs running Windows with additional language packs, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.

segment.source: This file can contain the default regional settings that you plan to show to the user.
segment.target: This file can contain the default regional settings that you plan to show to the user.

segment.source: You should also include a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.
segment.target: You should also include a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.

segment.source: This Oobe.xml should also contain the eulafilename node with the name of the custom license terms that you plan to use.
segment.target: This Oobe.xml should also contain the eulafilename node with the name of the custom license terms that you plan to use.

segment.source: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains unique customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.
segment.target: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains unique customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.

segment.source: After the user has chosen a country/region, this file is used to display additional customizations.
segment.target: After the user has chosen a country/region, this file is used to display additional customizations.

segment.source: For example, an English version of Windows that's delivered to the United States and Canada would use the following directory structure:
segment.target: For example, an English version of Windows that's delivered to the United States and Canada would use the following directory structure:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (logo, EULA file name, and regional settings)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (logo, EULA file name, and regional settings)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content)

segment.source: If you're delivering PCs to one or more countries/regions and are delivering PCs running Windows with additional language packs, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.
segment.target: If you're delivering PCs to one or more countries/regions and are delivering PCs running Windows with additional language packs, place an Oobe.xml file in %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo.

segment.source: This Oobe.xml file should contain the eulafilename node with the name of the customized EULA that you plan to use.
segment.target: This Oobe.xml file should contain the eulafilename node with the name of the customized EULA that you plan to use.

segment.source: Place an Oobe.xml for each Windows language that you're including in %WINDIR%System32Defaultlanguage that you're deploying in.
segment.target: Place an Oobe.xml for each Windows language that you're including in %WINDIR%System32Defaultlanguage that you're deploying in.

segment.source: These files should contain the default regional settings that you plan to show for a given language, as well as a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.
segment.target: These files should contain the default regional settings that you plan to show for a given language, as well as a default set of customizations, in case the user selects a country/region that you haven't made specific customizations for.

segment.source: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.
segment.target: Place an Oobe.xml file for each country/region that contains customized content in %WINDIR%System32country/region that you're deploying tolanguage that you're deploying in.

segment.source: After the user has chosen a country/region, this file is used to display your additional customizations.
segment.target: After the user has chosen a country/region, this file is used to display your additional customizations.

segment.source: For example, a version of Windows with English and French language packs that's delivered to the United States and Canada would use the following directory structure:
segment.target: For example, a version of Windows with English and French language packs that's delivered to the United States and Canada would use the following directory structure:

segment.source: Logo and EULA:
segment.target: Logo and EULA:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (logo and EULA file name)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoOobe.xml (logo and EULA file name)

segment.source: Regional settings and fallback for content that's not localized for the specific country/region:
segment.target: Regional settings and fallback for content that's not localized for the specific country/region:

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefault1033Oobe.xml (default regional settings and English content if the user chooses a country/region other than the United States or Canada)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefault1033Oobe.xml (default regional settings and English content if the user chooses a country/region other than the United States or Canada)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefault1036Oobe.xml (default regional settings and French content if the user chooses a country/region other than United States or Canada)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfoDefault1036Oobe.xml (default regional settings and French content if the user chooses a country/region other than United States or Canada)

segment.source: Country-specific or region-specific content in the appropriate languages
segment.target: Country-specific or region-specific content in the appropriate languages

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content in English)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441033Oobe.xml (United States custom content in English)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441036Oobe.xml (United States custom content in French)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo2441036Oobe.xml (United States custom content in French)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content in English)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391033Oobe.xml (Canada custom content in English)

segment.source: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391036Oobe.xml (Canada custom content in French)
segment.target: %WINDIR%System32OobeInfo391036Oobe.xml (Canada custom content in French)

segment.source: Country/region folder format
segment.target: Country/region folder format

segment.source: To identify the country/region:
segment.target: To identify the country/region:

segment.source: Look up the country/region GeoID identifier using the Table of Geographical Locations on MSDN.
segment.target: Look up the country/region GeoID identifier using the Table of Geographical Locations on MSDN.

segment.source: These values are presented in hexadecimal.
segment.target: These values are presented in hexadecimal.

segment.source: Convert the value from hexadecimal to decimal, and use that value for the folder name.
segment.target: Convert the value from hexadecimal to decimal, and use that value for the folder name.

segment.source: For example, to create a folder for Chile (GeoID 0x2E), name the folder "46".
segment.target: For example, to create a folder for Chile (GeoID 0x2E), name the folder "46".

segment.source: Language folder format
segment.target: Language folder format

segment.source: To identify the language, use the decimal version of the Locale ID (LCID) value.
segment.target: To identify the language, use the decimal version of the Locale ID (LCID) value.

segment.source: For example, to create a Spanish folder, name the folder "3082".
segment.target: For example, to create a Spanish folder, name the folder "3082".

segment.source: There are many more LCIDs than languages.
segment.target: There are many more LCIDs than languages.

segment.source: A few LCIDs correlate to the languages that can be released with Windows.
segment.target: A few LCIDs correlate to the languages that can be released with Windows.

segment.source: For more information about which languages release with Windows, at what level of localization, and their decimal identifiers, see Available Language Packs on TechNet.
segment.target: For more information about which languages release with Windows, at what level of localization, and their decimal identifiers, see Available Language Packs on TechNet.
